Difference is traditional wild card games (mlb for example) are win or go home. This is just for seeding, realistically they just need more statistical tiebreakers (see NFL divisional tie breakers)

It feels like they're leaving options on the table by resorting to off-screen coin flips. They could go to win % vs. same-conference teams or vs. other playoff teams. Total points captured or total eliminations scored is a last-resort tiebreaker, similar to other pro sports.
Unfair to the fans and viewers. I say again zero traditional sports leagues would have an off air unviewed wild card game
Good luck getting a road map out of them lol
I agree and there are a lot of people who will get paid and that's probably the real reason blizzard won't stream them they don't want to pay anyone more money

Well clearly that the operation @natenanzer is running. And I say this again to all the leadership at blizzard. Anything your team does or fails to do falls on you.we deserve a public statement and a road map on how you will do better for us in the future.

That would mirror how the LCS does it when the Head-to-head and record tiebreakers are met

If Team A attacks first against Team B and completes the payload map, then full holds, they'd get 3 map points. If Team A defended first and full held, the game would stop right when they passed where team B got to, only giving them 1 map point.

But then there's a distinct advantage to attacking first on a non-Control map (in whatever round ends up being last). If you attack second, the game stops as soon as you pass the furthest point the other team got to. 1/2
pic.twitter.com/xIXxoF3kKA

You need a better solution. Map differential, and if the teams were tied look to who has more map wins. It’s really easy.

It's definitely just an oversight. There's a lot done really well in the Overwatch League and I'm a big fan. Just something here that's disappointing, because I'd have enjoyed seeing that seeding play off match. As would many others I'm sure.

That's true, just seems a shame to say "This cool match is happening but nobody gets to see it." Very rare for any televised competition of any nature. They probably didn't anticipate this level of parity in the league. GOATS has been a big equaliser that way.
Because then the other teams don't get to watch an extra game worth of footage on us. I'm actually okay with this.
@LevvieNZ They're not letting us watch Seoul beat Shock :(
A coin flip and a non-broadcast match? This is how you make people not take eSports seriously.
Beats a coin flip. Heck, it beats a tie-breaker match where it can benefit you to throw.

I mean draws become less likely as the season goes on because there are more statistics to judge teams with. Dont be surprised if stage 2 doesnt even have draws because of how many more games they can judge teams by.
Good point

As the season goes on ties become less and less likely also head 2 head statistics start to come into it. With it only being stage 1 theres a very limited number of stats available to judge teams on. As they play more teams will start to drift apart.
Good chance teams asked it not to be broadcast so they can use all their strategies instead of hiding them for their next opponent, given both will make playoffs anyway.

At short notice yes for this stage, but with prep and changes next stage they could sort it. Could also use different rules for the standings so that these ties don't happen as frequently. Teams with the same map differential don't actually have the same percentage of maps won.

Yeah, it definitely could have been handled a lot cleaner. Keeping everyone in the dark until now just causes more issues. Going to give them the benefit of the doubt and hope they’ll fix it moving forward.

Let's put this in perspective. This year in the MLB they needed an extra game to decide 2 div/wildcards in the NL. Imagine if for one of those they flipped a coin and then for the other they played the "163" game. But didn't show it.
EXACTLY LOOOOOOOL
J'espère encore qu'on va m’appeler pour le commenter

I never said it was ok to not to; I just pointed out why they wouldn't because it makes sense. Casters? Paid OT. Viewing the players? Camera men. Paid OT. Want stats on your lower thirds? At least 1 stat person. Paid OT. Want any of this to work? Production team. Paid OT.
Streamé sur Twitch, le pile ou face ou pas ?

Perhaps, but I'd argue they need to change the rules on standings. Most leagues have ways to differentiate teams even if it's thin. Maybe percentage of maps won or something similar could work here. Teams have the same map differential but different maps won/lost in this stage.
